overview_of_class:
"This class will examine the representation of gender norms in Anglophone theatre from the early twentieth century to the present day. We will study such writers as Alice Childress, Angelina Weld Grimké, Susan Glaspell, Zona Gale, Sophie Treadwell, and Maria Irene Fornes. As we read these dramatic texts, we will also read classic texts of feminist theory and criticism, written at the same time as the plays we will be reading, by such writers as Simone De Beauvoir, Juliet Mitchell, Hélène Cixous, Luce Irigaray, and Michael Kimmel. In addition, we will compare these texts to the representation of gender norms in both popular and more avant-garde films of the time. Throughout the class, our view will be on understanding both the continuities and the changes in the conceptions and the performance of gender, both on the stage and in everyday life.

Students will have homework assignments, reading quizzes, two 3-4 page essays, and one 8-10 page essay.
"
name: Special Topics in History
topic: Staging Gender in 20th Century American Drama

overview_of_class: This course studies contemporary African plays and performances, each within a distinct cultural, political, and economic context. We will examine Death and the King's Horseman (Nigeria) by Wole Soyinka, Anowa (Ghana) by Ama Ata Aidoo, Amajuba (South Africa) by Yael Farber,The Rise and Shine of Camrade Fiasco (Zimbabwe) by Andrew Whaley, and The Other War (Eritrea) by Alemseged Tesfai. In addition to investigating these five plays within their greater contexts, students will be exposed to non-text based performance work in their specific contexts and contemporary issues in theatre within the African and international context. As a final project, students will choose a play or performance originating on the African continent for in-depth analysis and engagement, resulting in a final presentation and paper.
name: Special Topics in History

overview_of_class: Although the postmodern, avant-garde, and contemporary are widely perceived as genres emerging from and residing within the white West, artists of color outside of Euro-America are creating some of the most fascinating and complex work today. Through readings, viewings, and dance practice, this course encounters a handful of contemporary choreographers from sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, and Latin America. We will analyze their choreography through postcolonial and feminist perspectives in order to attend to the structural challenges that the artists face in the aftermath of colonialism and ongoing increasing global capitalism. The course asks: as contemporary dance is practiced in multiple sites across the world, what coheres in the category "contemporary dance"? This guiding question will be enriched by themes including transnational circulation, choreographies of anti-colonial resistance, global feminisms, national identity, state violence, and intercultural collaboration.
